body: @piiswrong And we used native network for the consideration of batchnorm. How can I implement batchnorm in mx.rnn and rnn.FusedCell?
@indhub this looks good to me. what is the build error?

if you are only applying batchnorm on output then you can used fusernncell by stacking them and insert bn in between.

if you are doing batchnorm on states between time steps then you can no longer use fused rnn cell

@reminisce Could you review?

I'm somewhat late on this but just in case someone is having the same problem. You *can* get the symbols for specific internal layers via the `[[` operator. So, for example, if your internals look like this:

~~~R
internals <- model$symbol$get.internals()
internals$outputs
# [1] "data"                    "fullyconnected27_weight" "fullyconnected27_bias"   "fullyconnected27_output" "fullyconnected28_weight" "fullyconnected28_bias"  
# [7] "fullyconnected28_output"
~~~

then `internals[[1]]` creates the symbol for `"data"`, `internals[[2]]` for `"fullyconnected27_weight"` and so on.

That said, this is not enough in order to access the internal predictions like in [the Python notebook](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/notebooks/predict-with-pretrained-model.ipynb). This is because the R implementation of `mx.model.FeedForward.create` always trains a model (so you can't reuse a symbol from a previous model like that).

Instead, what I have tried is to create a modified version of the [`predict.MXFeedForwardModel`](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/R-package/R/model.R#L473) function, which attempts to pass the necessary arguments to `mx.simple.bind` and `mx.exec.update.arg.arrays` so that only the layers upto the selected `layer` are used, and the outputs of the selected one are returned. Basically you should only need to manage which elements of `model$symbol$get.internals()$outputs` and `model$arg.params` are used inside the calls.

~~~R
predictInternal <- function(model, X, ctx=NULL, layer, array.batch.size=128, array.layout="auto") {
  # initialization stuff I probably don't care about ---------------------------
  if (is.null(ctx)) ctx <- mxnet:::mx.ctx.default()
  if (is.array(X) || is.matrix(X)) {
    if (array.layout == "auto") {
      array.layout <- mxnet:::mx.model.select.layout.predict(X, model)
    }
    if (array.layout == "rowmajor") {
      X <- t(X)
    }
  }
  # end initialization ---------------------------------------------------------
  # iterator creation ----------------------------------------------------------
  ## X iterates through the batches of input data
  X <- mxnet:::mx.model.init.iter(X, NULL, batch.size=array.batch.size, is.train=FALSE)
  X$reset()
  if (!X$iter.next()) stop("Cannot predict on empty iterator")
  dlist = X$value()
  # end iterator creation ------------------------------------------------------
  # executor creation ----------------------------------------------------------
  ## mx.simple.bind defined in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/R-package/R/executor.R#L5
  ## internally calls mx.symbol.bind, defined in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/R-package/src/executor.cc#L191
  ### see also: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/e7514fe1b3265aaf15870b124bb6ed0edd82fa76/R-package/demo/basic_executor.R
  # pexec <- mxnet:::mx.simple.bind(model$symbol, ctx=ctx, data=dim(dlist$data), grad.req="null")
  internals <- model$symbol$get.internals()
  pexec <- mxnet:::mx.simple.bind(internals[[1 + 3 * layer]], ctx=ctx, data=dim(dlist$data), grad.req="null")
  # end executor creation ------------------------------------------------------
  # set up arg arrays ----------------------------------------------------------
  internalArgParams <- model$arg.params[1:(2 * layer)]
  # print(names(internalArgParams))

  mxnet:::mx.exec.update.arg.arrays(pexec, internalArgParams, match.name=T)
  mxnet:::mx.exec.update.aux.arrays(pexec, model$aux.params, match.name=T)
  # end set up arg arrays ------------------------------------------------------
  # the rest is left untouched -------------------------------------------------
  packer <- mxnet:::mx.nd.arraypacker()
  X$reset()
  while (X$iter.next()) {
    dlist = X$value()
    mxnet:::mx.exec.update.arg.arrays(pexec, list(data=dlist$data), match.name=T)
    mxnet:::mx.exec.forward(pexec, is.train=FALSE)
    out.pred <- mxnet:::mx.nd.copyto(pexec$ref.outputs[[1]], mxnet:::mx.cpu())
    padded <- X$num.pad()
    oshape <- dim(out.pred)
    ndim <- length(oshape)
    packer$push(mxnet:::mx.nd.slice(out.pred, 0, oshape[[ndim]] - padded))
  }
  X$reset()
  return(packer$get())
}
~~~

Usage of this function, assuming we have a previously trained `model` and we want to get the outputs of the third hidden layer:

~~~R
predictInternal(model, trainX, layer = 3, array.layout = "colmajor", array.batch.size = 1)
~~~

I have tested this and works for my example case (but I don't have a toy example just yet). However it will not work for all cases, only for pretty specific and simple networks. I hope it's still helpful anyway.

maybe you will not believe it: same training code, but the bleeding edge version of mxnet is much slower than the mxnet0.8.0 in the 8 gpus machine, either ```kvstore=None``` or ```kvstore='device'```. specifically, if you use bleeding edge version of mxnet , 8gpus is much slower than 4gpus.

@Godricly ps-lite supports various data types. one can use templated SArray, such as SArray<int8>.  Internally ps-lite use char for communication. So any type with size >= sizeof(char) should be fine.
@mcxkarakoc WOW, ImageRecordIter_v1 works well. I found it has a lot of data augmentation methods. Could you give me some hints how to use them?

The source code is more recently (v0.9.5) moved to `mxnet/src/operator/contrib`, and adding to `EXTRA_OPERATORS` is no longer necessary. However, we should import `Proposal` by importing from `mxnet.contrib.symbol` instead of `mxnet.symbol` package. Hope this helps!~

I can write a short tutorials:

0. Install python 2 (if you have already installed py3 it will be fine) and git

1. Download windows nightly build or build it yourself and download "vc14 base package". Please use the lastest build, there are some bugs fixed. (There are some char encoding issues)

2. Read the README.txt and follow the instruction. **DO NOT RUN THE setupenv.cmd** because it will destory your %PATH% and can not do its job. Add the %PATH% yourself. You need to make sure libmxnet.dll and the 3rdpart' Dlls are in the %PATH%. Use `where libmxnet.dll` to check.

set %MXNET_HOME% to the folder contains setupenv.cmd

3. Install the python package. You might need to install numpy first.
```
cd %MXNET_HOME%\python
py -2 setup.py install
```

4. Download the [cpp-package](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/cpp-package). Put the include and src folder to %MXNET_HOME%.
```
cd %MXNET_HOME%\src\OpWrapperGenerator
py -2 OpWrapperGenerator.py libmxnet.dll
```
If you have some problem, you can change OpWrapperGenerator.py
```
os.system('./move-if-change.sh ' + temp_file_name + ' ' + output_file)
```
to
```
os.system('move-if-change.sh ' + temp_file_name + ' ' + output_file)
```

5. Check if there is a op.h file. If not, you might need to check all the things above.

6. Create a new msvc project. Set include folder to %MXNET_HOME%\include and library folder to %MXNET_HOME%\lib. 

7. Use this example to test if it is working.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/cpp-package/example/mlp.cpp

I think you need to change the include in order to let the complier to find the header.

You can use Python API doc to help you coding. But there are only SGD optimizer available, you need to ues lower level API (C interface) to use other optimizers.

@mli module has been updated, it would be more appropriate to change the argument `data_shapes`/`label_shapes` to `data_attrs`/`label_attrs` here(https://github.com/ZihengJiang/mxnet/blob/kvstore/python/mxnet/module/module.py#L323), but I keep it for compatible.
@kice Your label size is inconsistent with the label in record io. You should genereate correct data and try again.
Looks good to me.

This is due to the bulk execution in MXNet to reduce gaps between kernel launches. You can set 
MXNET_EXEC_BULK_EXEC_TRAIN = 0 
MXNET_EXEC_BULK_EXEC_INFERENCE = 0 
to disable it and see the time taken by individual op.
Many thanks.
@nikrao , there is no `CrossEntropyLoss` symbol in MXNet, `mx.sym.SoftmaxOutput()` implements the cross entropy loss, see [here](http://mxnet.io/api/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.SoftmaxOutput).

feedforward network?
